column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=X
#Text=THE Lake at last -- a sheet of shining metal brooded over by drooping trees .
#Text=Charity and Harney had secured a boat and , getting away from the wharves and the refreshment-booths , they drifted idly along , hugging the shadow of the shore .
#Text=Where the sun struck the water its shafts flamed back blindingly at the heat-veiled sky ; and the least shade was black by contrast .

#Text=The Lake was so smooth that the reflection of the trees on its edge seemed enamelled on a solid surface ; but gradually , as the sun declined , the water grew transparent , and Charity , leaning over , plunged her fascinated gaze into depths so clear that she saw the inverted tree-tops interwoven with the green growths of the bottom .
#Text=They rounded a point at the farther end of the Lake , and entering an inlet pushed their bow against a protruding tree-trunk .
#Text=A green veil of willows overhung them .
#Text=Beyond the trees , wheat-fields sparkled in the sun ; and all along the horizon the clear hills throbbed with light .
#Text=Charity leaned back in the stern , and Harney unshipped the oars and lay in the bottom of the boat without speaking .

#Text=Ever since their meeting at the Creston pool he had been subject to these brooding silences , which were as different as possible from the pauses when they ceased to speak because words were needless .

#Text=At such times his face wore the expression she had seen on it when she had looked in at him from the darkness and again there came over her a sense of the mysterious distance between them ; but usually his fits of abstraction were followed by bursts of gaiety that chased away the shadow before it chilled her .
#Text=She was still thinking of the ten dollars he had handed to the driver of the run-about .
#Text=It had given them twenty minutes of pleasure , and it seemed unimaginable that anyone should be able to buy amusement at that rate .
#Text=With ten dollars he might have bought her an engagement ring ; she knew that Mrs. Tom Fry 's , which came from Springfield , and had a diamond in it , had cost only eight seventy-five .
#Text=But she did not know why the thought had occurred to her .
#Text=Harney would never buy her an engagement ring : they were friends and comrades , but no more .
#Text=He had been perfectly fair to her : he had never said a word to mislead her .
#Text=She wondered what the girl was like whose hand was waiting for his ring ... .
#Text=Boats were beginning to thicken on the Lake and the clang of incessantly arriving trolleys announced the return of the crowds from the ball-field .
#Text=The shadows lengthened across the pearl-grey water and two white clouds near the sun were turning golden .
#Text=On the opposite shore men were hammering hastily at a wooden scaffolding in a field .
#Text=Charity asked what it was for .
#Text=“ Why , the fireworks .
#Text=I suppose there 'll be a big show . ”
#Text=Harney looked at her and a smile crept into his moody eyes .
#Text=“ Have you never seen any good fireworks ? ”
#Text=“ Miss Hatchard always sends up lovely rockets on the Fourth , ” she answered doubtfully .
#Text=“ Oh -- -- ” his contempt was unbounded .
#Text=“ I mean a big performance like this , illuminated boats , and all the rest . ”
#Text=She flushed at the picture .
#Text=“ Do they send them up from the Lake , too ? ”
#Text=“ Rather .
#Text=Did n't you notice that big raft we passed ?
#Text=It 's wonderful to see the rockets completing their orbits down under one 's feet . ”
#Text=She said nothing , and he put the oars into the rowlocks .
#Text=“ If we stay we 'd better go and pick up something to eat . ”
#Text=“ But how can we get back afterwards ? ” she ventured , feeling it would break her heart if she missed it .
#Text=He consulted a time-table , found a ten o'clock train and reassured her .
#Text=“ The moon rises so late that it will be dark by eight , and we 'll have over an hour of it . ”
#Text=Twilight fell , and lights began to show along the shore .
#Text=The trolleys roaring out from Nettleton became great luminous serpents coiling in and out among the trees .
#Text=The wooden eating-houses at the Lake 's edge danced with lanterns , and the dusk echoed with laughter and shouts and the clumsy splashing of oars .
#Text=Harney and Charity had found a table in the corner of a balcony built over the Lake , and were patiently awaiting an unattainable chowder .
#Text=Close under them the water lapped the piles , agitated by the evolutions of a little white steamboat trellised with coloured globes which was to run passengers up and down the Lake .
#Text=It was already black with them as it sheered off on its first trip .
#Text=Suddenly Charity heard a woman 's laugh behind her .
#Text=The sound was familiar , and she turned to look .

#Text=A band of showily dressed girls and dapper young men wearing badges of secret societies , with new straw hats tilted far back on their square-clipped hair , had invaded the balcony and were loudly clamouring for a table .
#Text=The girl in the lead was the one who had laughed .
#Text=She wore a large hat with a long white feather , and from under its brim her painted eyes looked at Charity with amused recognition .
#Text=“ Say ! if this ai n't like Old Home Week , ” she remarked to the girl at her elbow ; and giggles and glances passed between them .
#Text=Charity knew at once that the girl with the white feather was Julia Hawes .

#Text=She had lost her freshness , and the paint under her eyes made her face seem thinner ; but her lips had the same lovely curve , and the same cold mocking smile , as if there were some secret absurdity in the person she was looking at , and she had instantly detected it .
